questions.description: Needs to be admired and seeks special treatment across situations.
Relationships swing between idealizing and devaluing people.
Uses charm or intensity to influence others, then withdraws when not admired.
Sets aside others' needs when they conflict with personal goals.
Feels superior or entitled and expects exceptions to rules.
Fantasizes about exceptional success, power, or attractiveness.
Competes for recognition and compares achievements constantly.
Blames circumstances or others more than self when mistakes happen.
Fear of abandonment (real or imagined) triggers strong reactions.
Feelings toward someone change drastically within hours.
Tests others' loyalty or becomes anxious without reassurance.
Feels empty when not connected or validated by others.
Alternates between intense pursuit and cutting ties after conflict.
Anger can be intense and hard to calm when perceiving rejection.
Self-image shifts depending on who is present.
Experiences dissociation or unreality during high stress.
Uses dramatic expression (voice, gestures, appearance) to secure attention.
Feels uncomfortable when not the center of attention.
Emotions shift rapidly to match context or audience.
Speech or stories are embellished to seem more engaging.
Prioritizes appearance or charm to influence outcomes.
Relationships may feel superficial or driven by impression management.
Engages in impulsive acts (spending, sex, driving, substances) despite risk.
Acts quickly to avoid distress even when consequences are negative.
Bends rules or deceives to gain advantage.
Feels little remorse after harming or exploiting others.
Prefers immediate rewards over long-term planning.
Irritable or aggressive when blocked from goals.
Disregards safety of self or others when acting on impulses.
Takes credit for group work or minimizes others' contributions.
Finds it hard to sustain work or study without external pressure.
Relationships can be transactional; keeps score of favors or loyalty.

carreras.description: Work on tolerating critique, acknowledging others' wins, and building self-esteem not tied to admiration. Consider therapies focusing on self-concept and interpersonal feedback.
Gradual closeness, consistent boundaries, and DBT/mentalization skills can reduce swings and abandonment fear. Seek clinical support if emotions feel unmanageable.
Practice grounded communication, check facts before reacting, and cultivate authenticity over performance. Psychoeducation on interpersonal effectiveness can help.
Develop delay-of-gratification, empathy exercises, and accountability routines. Clinical assessment is advised when risk, deception, or aggression are present.

labels.HeroSubtitle: Not a diagnosis. Combines items from multiple clinical checklists to map patterns across Cluster B traits.
labels.MethodNote: Self-exploration tool. Not diagnostic. Items combine psychoeducational criteria for Cluster B traits to support clinical conversations.
labels.MethodSummaryScoring: Percent is based on your "yes" responses per dimension; more "yes" means higher reported frequency.
labels.MethodDetail: Questions blend content inspired by DSM-5 personality disorder criteria, SCID-5-PD and IPDE screening prompts, PNI/NPI (narcissistic facets), PAI-BOR/DBT-informed items (borderline), Histrionic PD psychoeducation, and antisocial/impulse-control checklists. Scores reflect proportional yes-responses within each trait cluster; ranking highlights where you report more features.
MethodReferences: APA. DSM-5-TR Personality Disorders (Cluster B criteria).
First MB et al. SCID-5-PD, 2016; IPDE screening items.
Pincus AL et al. Pathological Narcissism Inventory; Raskin & Hall, NPI.
Morey LC. Personality Assessment Inventory (PAI-BOR scales).
Linehan MM. DBT skills training (emotion regulation, distress tolerance).
